name: Role-Based Access and IAM Best Practices
description: Key concepts and best practices for managing roles and access in AWS using IAM and Identity Providers

cards.front: Your organization wants to grant employees temporary credentials when accessing AWS, instead of long-term credentials. What IAM feature should you use?
cards.back: Use IAM roles, which provide temporary security credentials that automatically expire, making them safer than permanent user credentials.
cards.example: Instead of giving developers access keys, they assume a 'DevAccess' role and receive temporary credentials that expire in 1 hour.
cards.subject: Role Based Access in AWS

cards.front: You're building a web app and need sign-up and login functionality for users. Should you use IAM to manage this?
cards.back: No, IAM is meant to manage identities within your AWS account, not external website users. Use Amazon Cognito or another identity service for web authentication.
cards.example: A blog site requires users to create accounts. IAM is not suitable here; Cognito would be the better choice.
cards.mnemonic: IAM is for Infrastructure, not Internet Users
cards.subject: Role Based Access in AWS

cards.front: You want to manage employee access to multiple AWS accounts using a central identity source. What should you implement?
cards.back: Use an identity provider (IdP) with IAM roles to federate access. This allows centralized identity management outside of AWS.
cards.example: Your company uses Okta to manage users. By federating Okta with IAM, you avoid creating IAM users in every AWS account.
cards.subject: Role Based Access in AWS

cards.front: Your company wants employees to log in once and access all their assigned AWS accounts and applications. What AWS service supports this?
cards.back: AWS IAM Identity Center allows users to sign in with a single set of credentials and access multiple accounts and applications through a central portal.
cards.example: Martha signs in once to AWS IAM Identity Center and gains access to both dev and prod AWS accounts with her assigned roles.
cards.subject: Role Based Access in AWS

cards.front: Youâ€™re writing an IAM policy for a developer. What is the best way to apply the principle of least privilege?
cards.back: Start with the minimal required permissions and add more only as needed. This limits risk and ensures controlled access.
cards.example: A developer only needs S3 read access, so you create a policy allowing 's3:GetObject' rather than granting full S3 access.
cards.subject: Role Based Access in AWS
